trans-unit.source: Allows you to override attributes applied to properties, fields, and classes when you use an <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer"></xref> to serialize or deserialize an object as encoded SOAP.
The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides> class enables an <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> to override the default way of serializing a set of objects.

Overriding serialization in this way has two uses: first, you can control and augment the serialization of objects found in a DLL, even if you do not have access to the source; second, you can create one set of serializable classes, but serialize the objects in multiple ways.
For example, instead of serializing members of a class instance as XML elements, you can serialize them as XML attributes, resulting in a more efficient document to transport.

After you create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>, you create an <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlTypeMapping> using the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapReflectionImporter.ImportTypeMapping%2A> method of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapReflectionImporter> class.
Pass the resulting object as an argument to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.%23ctor%2A> constructor.

The resulting <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> uses the data contained by the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides> to override attributes that control how objects are serialized.

To accomplish this, the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides> contains a collection of the object types that are overridden, as well as a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> associated with each overridden object type.
Each <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> contains an appropriate set of attribute objects that control how each field, property, or class is serialized.
The process for creating and using a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides> is as follows:
Create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes>.
Create an attribute object that is appropriate to the object being overridden.
For example, to override a field or property, create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapElementAttribute>, using the new, derived type.
You can optionally assign a new <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapElementAttribute.ElementName%2A> that overrides the base class's attribute name or namespace.
Add the attribute object to the appropriate <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> property or collection.

For example, you would set the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes.SoapElement%2A> property of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> object to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapElementAttribute> and specify the member name that is being overridden.
Create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>.
Add the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides> using the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlAttributeOverrides.Add%2A> method.
If the object being overridden is a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapTypeAttribute>, you need only specify the type of the overridden object.
But if you are overriding a field or property, you must also specify the name of the overridden member.

Create an <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlTypeMapping> using the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapReflectionImporter.ImportTypeMapping%2A> method of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapReflectionImporter> class.

When constructing the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer>, pass the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlTypeMapping> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
Use the resulting <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> to serialize or deserialize the class objects.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides"></xref> class.
Adds a <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> to a collection of <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> objects.
The type parameter specifies an object to be overridden by the .

The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> contains a union of attribute objects that cause the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> to override its default serialization behavior for a set of objects.
You choose the attribute objects to place in the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes>, depending on the particular behaviors you want to override.
For example, the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> serializes a class member as an XML element by default.

If you want the member to be serialized as an XML attribute instead, you would create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeAttribute>, assign it to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes.SoapAttribute%2A> property of a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes>, and add the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlAttributes> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>.
Use the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides.Add%2A> method to add the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>.
Use this overload to add a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> that contains a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapTypeAttribute>.
Because the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapTypeAttribute> overrides the serialization of a class, you need not specify a member of the class to override, only the type of the class.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the object that is overridden.
A <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> that represents the overriding attributes.

Adds a <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> to the collection of <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> objects contained by the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides"></xref>.
The type parameter specifies the object to be overridden by the .
The member parameter specifies the name of a member that is overridden.

The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> contains a union of attribute objects that cause the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> to override its default serialization behavior for a set of objects.
You choose the attribute objects to place in the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes>, depending on the particular behaviors you want to override.
For example, the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> serializes a class member as an XML element by default.

If you want the member to be serialized as a SOAP attribute instead, you would create a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeAttribute>, assign it to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes.SoapAttribute%2A> property of a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes>, and add the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlAttributes> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>.
Use the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides.Add%2A> method to add the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> to the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeOverrides>.

Use this method when the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> contains either a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeAttribute>, <xref:System.ComponentModel.DefaultValueAttribute><xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapElementAttribute>, <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapEnumAttribute>, or <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapIgnoreAttribute>.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the object to override.
The name of the member to override.
A <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> that represents the overriding attributes.
Gets the object associated with the specified (base class) type.
Use this overload to return a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> that contains attributes for a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapTypeAttribute>.
The base class <xref href="System.Type"></xref> that is associated with the collection of attributes you want to retrieve.
A <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> that represents the collection of overriding attributes.
Gets the object associated with the specified (base class) type.
The member parameter specifies the base class member that is overridden.

Use this overload to return a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> that contains attributes that override a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributeAttribute>, <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapElementAttribute>, <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapIgnoreAttribute>, or <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapEnumAttribute>.
You can also return a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> that contains the override of a default value that uses a <xref:System.ComponentModel.DefaultValueAttribute>.
If the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes> contains a <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.SoapTypeAttribute>, you must use the overload that specifies only the overridden type.
The base class <xref href="System.Type"></xref> that is associated with the collection of attributes you want to override.
The name of the overridden member that specifies the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> to return.
A <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.SoapAttributes"></xref> that represents the collection of overriding attributes.
